text: Marked by blood, bound by steel, Tuula leads with a whisper and kills with precision.
She offers no prayers—only blood. And the Blood God listens.
At tribal moots, Tuula’s voice cuts through growls and boasts like her axe through bone.
Tuula doesn’t rage—she stalks, she waits, she kills.
Unlike others, Tuula did not beg for Khorne’s gaze. She earned it—and resents nothing.
Tuula sees more than the moment—she sees the outcome, and bends the present to meet it.
Khorne watches Tuula closely, for her fury is focused, not mindless.
Tuula and Olaf are more than husband and wife—they are war-forged soulmates.
Marked by blood, bound by steel, Tuula leads with a whisper and kills with precision.
Chosen by no one, claimed by nothing—Tuula Bloodhair carves her fate in blood alone.
It whispers not to Tuula, but to her prey—the sound of it tearing flesh is like a name spoken backwards.
Her words are few, but the weight they carry drives her warriors beyond fear, beyond pain, beyond mercy.
When Tuula is near, Olaf becomes more than a warrior—he becomes the hand of wrath itself.

There are weapons that roar, and weapons that sing—but Woundtongue whispers. Forged from warped blacksteel and tipped with blood that never dries, the axe earned its name from the way it slides into flesh like a secret. It does not cleave with brute force but slices with uncanny precision, finding the spaces between ribs, beneath plate, and under thought. Some say Tuula did not forge it, nor win it—but woke with it clutched in her hands after a night of dreams she does not recall. Its edge was already stained red.
Marauder mobs are awarded even greater mobility when riding their crude chariots of bone and wood, lashed together with the guts and sinew of the vanquished.
Marauder mobs are awarded even greater mobility when riding their crude chariots of bone and wood, lashed together with the guts and sinew of the vanquished.
Marauder mobs are awarded even greater mobility when riding their crude chariots of bone and wood, lashed together with the guts and sinew of the vanquished.
Silent in step and savage in strike, Tuula leads not with rage, but with cold, crimson purpose.
